text: Yes, the school board invites and actively seeks the public's input in the mess in the matters relevant to school board governance and provides for time, doing its business meetings to hear from my county residents and community members doing public comment, we expect respectful and on topic comments.  As authorized by ordinance of the County of Albemarle, the school board will hold its meetings electronically during the COVID-19 pandemic. The school board is nevertheless committed to encouraging public comment despite its need to meet on a virtual basis. For this reason, there will be two ways for the public to provide comment. First, as always, they may be submitted to the school board clerk prior to the start of the meeting and will be disseminated to all of the school board members for review.  Secondly, members of the public wishing to provide public comment during the school boards meeting may sign up online at our website by 4pm the day before the meeting, the clerk will email zoom links to the speakers on the day of the meeting, so that they can log into the meeting to provide comment.  Before electronic public comment commences, the vice chair will announce the order in which the speakers will comment. Public commenters will initially be admitted to a waiting room area on Zoom until it is their turn to speak. There, they'll be able to hear the meeting in progress while they wait. Each speaker's access to public comment will be activated when it is that speaker's turn to provide comment to the members of the school board.  The speakers will be notified when they reach the two-minute mark. And at the three-minute mark, the speaker's Zoom link will be automatically deactivated. Although the school board is confident that public comment will proceed in an orderly and respectful manner, upon instruction from the chair, the clerk has the ability to disconnect a speaker who is disruptive, profane, or fails to abide by these guidelines.  Speakers during the meeting or those submitting written comment should state name and address or magisterial district. Simply stating Albemarle County is not adequate. The school board will not respond to comments made during the public comment period. School board members may address comments at the end of the meeting agenda under other business. And tonight we have five speakers.  They will speak in this order. Vernon Leichty, Murray Sekalski, whose name I butchered, Kevin Owen, Amy Gardner, and Cheryl Knight. Those are our five speakers for tonight. Ms. Johnson.

text: I'm Vernon Lectee. I'm a teacher at Elmorrow High School, and I currently vote in the Jack Jewett District. I'm here to talk about collective bargaining. As public school teachers, my colleagues and I have been humbled by the support we receive from the parents, the board, and the public during the coronavirus pandemic. We've all seen posts on social media from folks who say things like, we should pay teachers a million dollars, or I didn't realize that their jobs are so hard.  While we appreciate the sentiment, most teachers will tell you that they don't need a million dollars. What we need is the dignity of a voice on the job. For those that are not aware, collective bargaining is simply a process of negotiation between employers and their employees. Police, firefighters, and teachers have concerns related to workload, compensation, staffing levels, and safety. We want to make sure that classrooms are not overcrowded and that emergency responders have the resources they need because our work conditions affect the vast majority of Virginians.  Collective bargaining allows localities to partner up with their employees, so they better understand these concerns and work together to address them. Fortunately, the General Assembly of Virginia has passed legislation that could grant Albemarle employees collective bargaining rights. The legislation empowers the localities and the school boards to give us those collective bargaining rights. This law will go into effect in May of 2021, and is now up to the school board to give the employees these rights.  There is no inherent cost to collective bargaining. Giving teachers the power to negotiate a contract does not mean the school boards or localities are forced to spend money that they don't have. Rather, collective bargaining is about working within the realm of what is possible to achieve the best possible result for everyone. Workers who are on the ground are often in the best position to identify inefficiencies and waste that they witnessed firsthand. Furthermore, teachers' working conditions are the students' learning conditions. We want smaller class sizes so that we can give your children more attention.  We want adequate planning time so that our students can get high quality lessons. And we want a consistent discipline policy so that consequences are fair across the board and not influenced by influential racial bias. Our contracts typically run in the ranges of two pages. The wording is intentionally vague and teachers feel pressure to take on extra responsibilities without additional time or additional compensation. We need clarity and we need protection. So many people in the past few weeks have expressed their respect for our teachers, firefighters, and public sector workers  who continue to deliver essential services through this pandemic. But you can't support teachers if you don't support giving us the freedom to join a union and bargain collectively, as our counterparts in the private sector can do. Our students deserve the best. This school division is stepping up to ensure our students have the support they need to finish the semester. We're not turning back on these kids in the middle of a pandemic, and we're asking that our elected leaders not turn their backs on us. I encourage the Albemarle County School Board and the Albemarle County Board of Supervisors to grant its employees the right to collectively bargain.  Listen to firefighters, police, and teachers. Show us that you truly do respect our professional opinions and give us a seat at the table. Thank you.

I'd like to talk today and ask a little bit about the decision-making process on whether or not to open schools and how to do that. text: Yeah, I'd also like to ask that the decision to open the schools is made on a local basis. We're not Northern Virginia, we're not Richmond, it's a different situation.  I know we've been closed for two months now. It will be three months by the end of the year. I think everyone can agree it's been an awful experience for all of us. Kids have missed education. The online schooling has been good, but it's not the same thing. I'm also much more worried about the mental health impact. I know that my kids are beginning to be depressed. And if we don't open in the fall, we'll be doing an experiment on what happens if you don't let kids socialize for nine months. That's never been done before. And these are the ages where they have  learn and the brains have to rewire and socialize with the peers and do it that way. So if we don't reopen, then I'm afraid that will be a very, very bad situation. And I mentioned data before. I know that it wasn't necessarily a popular thing to close all the schools for the whole year at the beginning when there wasn't much data. And it was probably the wise decision. But I'm a PhD scientist, and I've looked at some of the data out there. And there's a couple of pieces of evidence. One is that  Out of the 75, 80,000 deaths in COVID so far, there's only four kids in the five to 14 age range that have died, which implies that if we open schools, it would not be a danger to the kids. And also there's a risk of the kids coming home and affecting the parents, which is a real risk. But we also have an experiment going on in Sweden where they did not close the schools and their deaths and infections were only about a third higher than us. Yet in Stockholm,  they have 30% immunity and they expect by the end of the summer, they'll have herd immunity. So they, they traded off something there. Um, so I, I just like to ask that we use data and stuff like that. And unfortunately, as we know, you know, if school boards can decide we'd like to open, um, they can be overridden by the governor. I would like to ask that school board considers ways to get ahead of that and maybe communicate with the governor and request that it would be a local decision.  for the benefit of the local parents and kids. And also maybe talk to some other school boards. If you could have 10 school boards that all feel the same way, let us make the decision not have a blanket one size fits all decision and maybe do like a newspaper editorial about that. That might be a good way to let this be a local decision. And so that we could all have some kind of agency because I know that, you know, some parents will leave the state if the schools don't open and they can't work. I mean, that's how I feel.  If there's six months of no school, and we can't work, it's untenable, we'll be sending the kids to go stay with grandma or something like that. It's not a good situation. But thanks for the opportunity to talk to you guys, and I hope you guys come to the right decision about opening the schools in the fall.

text: Good evening, members of the school board, Dr. Haas, and other central office staff personnel. My name is Amy Gartner, and I live in the Whitehall District. Thank you for your work that has gone into preparing a new budget. I know it has been very discouraging to see new programs and services you supported having to be cut. We are all concerned about meeting the needs of a growing population of students with fewer resources  Employees are disheartened that our raises are gone. Many of us have lost our second and third jobs. The financial stress of being an educator is now compounded by concerns for our students, their families, our families, and our own health. We are home with our family, and we are also supporting, encouraging, and engaging the families of our students. Matt was right. This is a marathon. We are training and preparing for the next race, and we are not to the finish line of this one. Educators have been asking questions and have many concerns.  Teachers are apprehensive about signing new contracts when they do not know what they will be expected to do in order to honor their contracts. We will need to be given copies of our entire contract before signing them this year. Will educators and students be tested before returning to school to find out if we have the virus or have asymptomatic carrier? Elementary students will not keep their mask on their face or keep their hands off their face. Elementary students should not be expected to keep their hands to themselves. They're kinesthetic learners.  There are county employees of underlining medical issues and care for family members who have underlining medical conditions. Do we know how many employees fall into these categories? I would like PD this summer to help me talk with my students, their parents, and my colleagues about the trauma of this pandemic. I would love more mindfulness training to help me and other educators manage stress. In my career, I've been to three funerals of student family members. In my first year, a seventh grade brother of a student died from leukemia.  11 years ago, one of my students' mothers was diagnosed with breast cancer in October and passed away just before Mother's Day. The grade level team of teachers attended both funerals. Two years ago, I attended the funeral of a student's grandmother. There are numerous blessings of living, teaching, and worshiping in the same community, but there are also moments when I carry the grief of a family and my neighbors close to my heart. I was the family's deacon. I took a half a day personal day to be with family at the funeral.  There will be many family members and students who will get sick and some will pass away. Will there be a funeral? Will staff be able, allowed, or expected to go to funerals? Will we need to take personal days in order to attend funerals? How will the county help students and staff manage their emotions when someone passes away? I've been playing the role of a counselor, but I'm not trained to help people I love manage the layers of worries brought on by the pandemic. Educators are tired of staying at home. We miss our students.  But this is still a deadly virus. And we want to know that our students and staff are safe before schools are opened. Thank you.

text: So I've been researching a disease called macular degeneration. And this is a blinding condition that affects over 200 million people around the world. The vast majority of the cases, about 90%, are what's called the dry type of macular degeneration. And there is no FDA-approved treatment for this form of the disease, which often leads to irreversible blindness in people over the age of 50.  They lose the ability to read, watch TV, and sometimes even see faces. This horrible disease strips patients of their most important sense, robbing them of their humanity.  Dry macular degeneration causes blindness by killing cells in the center of the retina, known as the macula, effectively punching holes in patients' vision. As this disease has no treatment, I wanted to find the first therapy. Traditional drug development costs billions of dollars and over a decade of research and testing. Instead, I focused on finding a drug that's already FDA approved for another disease and testing whether it could be repurposed for this one.  I discovered that fluoxetine, also known as Prozac, which is used to treat depression, could be repurposed as potentially the first treatment for dry macular degeneration. My novel repurposing method dramatically decreases the time and cost of creating a treatment. In my experiments, I tested fluoxetine in cells, retinal tissue, and a health insurance database covering 25 million patients. I found that fluoxetine was able to protect retinal cells and animal models from retinal degeneration.  In addition, I performed a retrospective study in a large health insurance database and found that patients taking fluoxetine had a much lower risk of developing macular degeneration. I'm excited that my work can be translated from the lab to the patients quickly, saving millions. I'm also really excited about continuing to work on this project, and I'm aiming to launch prospective randomized clinical trials as soon as possible so that we can develop the very first treatment for this blinding disease. Thank you.  Extraordinary.

text: OK, great. Yeah, so my project was the application of mathematical modeling to herd immunity.  So pretty much, I use mathematical modeling in my project, which allows me to use coding and programming to create agents, define parameters, and identify emerging properties and behaviors. And this can be applied to an abundance of things, from traders' behavior during a financial crisis, with the recent upshifts and downswings we've seen in the stock market, to what I decided to focus on, which is the spread of infectious diseases after an outbreak.  And I decided to take a slightly different approach than normal mathematical models, as most of them are based on differential equations, and they require the mathematician or programmer to make assumptions on the data. And I decided to take a slightly different approach in factoring in this component of variability, which will allow the model to predict without priorly existing data, and we'll be able to predict novel things such as COVID-19, where nobody really knows how it's going to turn out.  So more specifically in my project, I focused on herd immunity, which is the amount of a population that has to be vaccinated and or immune against a disease to protect the population as a whole. This is important not only to prevent against outbreaks, but to protect those who can't protect themselves, such as children who aren't old enough to get vaccinated, elderly who vaccinations are less effective for, cancer patients, transplant patients, or pretty much anybody with a weakened immune system. And I wanted to see how many people have to be vaccinated in order to protect these people.  More specifically, I decided to focus on measles, because it is the leading cause of preventable by vaccination death worldwide, and the vaccination contains a live virus, which means we know there are people with a weakened immune system who can't get it.  So I coded and modified and coded and modified and ran over 500 simulations and I was able to create a validated model that had numbers almost identical to that of real world measles examples. And from there, I was able to see two kind of major results. First one was that herd immunity in measles is nonlinear.  I graphed out how many, as we increase vaccination rates, how does infection rates, what happens to the infection rates. And as vaccination rates increase, we see an exponential decrease in infections. This means that contrary to popular anti-vax belief that vaccination statuses don't matter, with an exponential decrease, we see that really every single vaccination status matters.  In fact, the 2019 Brooklyn neighborhood outbreak, which had 9% vaccination rate and 650 people infected, if they'd increased to simply a third of the population being vaccinated, they could have seen an 80% decrease in infections. For reference, Charlottesville has a 96% vaccination rate, so a third of the population being vaccinated really isn't that much.  My second result, which is why I set out to do this project, is how many people have to be vaccinated to ensure that we're protecting the population as a whole, as well as those with a weakened immune system who aren't lucky enough to be able to protect themselves. And I found that we may need to achieve 93% or greater vaccination rates to enable measles herd immunity.  Lastly, the future applications of my model. So because in the beginning I factored in this component of variability, the model is able to predict without priorly existing data and without forcing the mathematician or programmer to make assumptions. This means that the model can predict things such as the novel COVID-19 and it can actually be directly translated to COVID-19 to work to answer questions about the efficacy of hygiene measures such as quarantining, social distancing,  and the new idea of introducing a vaccine that may not be 100% effective. And outside of infectious diseases, the model can also be translated to things such as the 2020 presidential election to identify the effect of social media influence on voters. Thank you so much.

text: I have an announcement. Thank you, Mr. O'Carroll. It is not possible today to turn to a radio or TV or website or to pick up a newspaper without reading about the very best in our country.  Every day we are learning about those who had great personal risk and sacrifice of putting the interests of others ahead of their own. What would we do without them. It is one of life's great ironies that in times of tragedy that our community best learns about those who routinely dedicate their lives to the service of others.  We admire those on the front lines of our hospitals, clinics, and medical offices. We are grateful for their courage and their selfless dedication. I want to tell you about another such hero who comes from a different place.  A recent NPR story was about a student in another part of the country who said about her educator, and I quote, she wasn't just concerned about me getting good grades. She was concerned about me being a good human being in life. She would always ask me how my mom is doing because my mom was kind of sick. Things like that she didn't have to do because it wasn't school related.  She built my confidence up because I was so insecure about being smart, or the skills that I wanted to have, or the goals that I wanted in life. I could always hear her telling me, you belong here." End of quote. The student went on to say how in the midst of the COVID-19 crisis, she reached for her phone to text a message, and how she stopped in mid-sentence, realizing she would not get a reply.  Her friend, the teacher, was among the hundreds of educators across this country who had lost their lives to COVID-19. Here in Albemarle County, we know about the contributions our teachers make in the classroom every day of the school year. We know about their creativity, the determination, the passion, and the joy of our educators bringing to the lives of our children.  We measure that on tests and examinations. We calculate that in our graduation rates. We celebrate that in the academic awards our students earn. And even tonight with the three young ladies that we heard.  Less visible, but deeper in value, more life-changing is what is not captured by a number. It is revealed in the comments of the student in the NPR story, in the self-esteem, confidence, friendship, trust, and kindness she gained from an educator. As a teacher for 24 years with Albemarle County Public Schools, I had the privilege of working next to hundreds and hundreds of educators who provided these gifts to the students.  Here's what one of our parents in the midst of the current COVID-19 crisis wrote on Facebook. And again, I quote, with joy to listen to my fourth grader talk to his fabulous teacher. It is hard to tell who is more enthusiastic. I know this time away from students is soul crushing for teachers who've dedicated their lives to educating our children. And while the public health restrictions in place to protect us from COVID-19 make this anything but a normal time, they do not diminish the everyday accomplishments and attributes of these highly dedicated and extraordinary professionals. text: So good evening board members. I'm Pat McLaughlin, chief of strategic planning for the school division. And I'm here tonight to get some feedback from you about our 2020 school board retreat. So each year, typically in June, the board holds a day long annual retreat at a local venue.  Prior to our retreat, it's important to consider why we hold retreats in the first place. The National School Boards Association has conducted research on characteristics of effective school boards, and a yearly board retreat promotes several of those characteristics, including providing time to commit to a collective vision for the district and to set goals toward achieving that vision, providing an opportunity to focus on policies to improve student achievement, continuing to strengthen the collaboration and trust to work as a unified team, and providing an opportunity to build shared knowledge  values, and commitments. So the purpose of a board retreat is to provide the board with an extended period of dedicated work time. We know that one of the challenges of being on a public board such as this is the somewhat limited opportunities that exist for all seven board members to work together on agenda items of their choosing for a meaningful period of time. The majority of a successful retreat is spent in time that's dedicated to your collaborative work with each other.  In addition, as outlined in policies BBA and CBA, the yearly responsibilities of the school board include a self-evaluation of the board's work, as well as an annual performance evaluation of the superintendent. In past years, the board has used the annual retreat as an opportunity to accomplish both of those tasks.  So this year conducting a board retreat obviously presents some unique challenges. Goals for tonight's meeting include gathering feedback from board members about when, where and how you would like to hold the annual retreat and to discuss potential agenda items that are of interest for inclusion by the board. I'll discuss some options for meeting logistics and meeting agenda items tonight and then we'll give the board time to discuss what they think will be the best plan moving forward. So there's at least three options for holding a retreat this year.  Option one would be socially distanced in-person retreat. If we hold that in phase one, we would limit to 10 in-person participants, which would probably be the board, the clerk, the superintendent, and the chief of strategic planning, which is me. Other participants certainly could participate online, and the meeting would be open to the public online.  Option two could be a fully online retreat. I think we've all lived through a lot of Zoom meetings lately, and if we choose that, we may want to consider a more limited format than the all-day retreat to be together on Zoom. And then option three would be to delay the retreat until phase two, when perhaps we could have more live participants who could attend. Currently, the retreat is scheduled on June 5th, and we can certainly be flexible with that date. And in a moment, we'll have a little bit of time to discuss the format and the date  of the retreat. So once we have the logistics decided, then we can determine the agenda for the retreat.  Based on feedback from past board retreats, these events are generally most successful when staff members provide requested background material, data, and research on topics that are of interest to the board, and then step away to let the board members drive the conversation. Staff members stay on site and are prepared to offer insights and information when needed throughout the day, but this is really the school board retreat, and the agenda should largely be driven by what you see as the most important policy topics for the school division right now.  So with that said, we wanted to provide a couple of suggestions to the board tonight to begin your thinking about the retreat. Possible topics for you to consider at the retreat include the board self-evaluation and the superintendent's evaluation. Again, both of those are required by policy. So if not completed at the retreat, we would need to work that into a future meeting.  In addition to that, we'll soon be entering the recovery phase of student learning due to our COVID-19 closure. And that may be a pressing issue for the board to discuss. And finally, we hope to relaunch the process of building a new division strategic plan in September. And board feedback on the direction of that plan and the planning process is really crucial.  Discussions of what learning looks like as we eventually return to school could possibly have a significant impact on where we focus our efforts in our strategic plan. So these topics are simply a starting point for suggestions. And if we elect not to include them to the retreat, we can bring them back to future work sessions for the board.  So tonight I'd like to hear from the board members about your preferences. The first question we should address are the retreat logistics, the when, where, and how we would like to meet. We discussed three potential options, but that's certainly not an exhaustive list. And I'd like to open the floor to the board at this time for some feedback on that. So board members, any thoughts about the when, where, and how for our 2020 retreat?

text: Good evening, everyone. I hope everyone is doing well. One of my responsibilities with the Department of Technology is to keep our current projects moving to make sure we meet milestones and important deadlines. I also work  to make sure we have relationships and partnerships with the other departments throughout our school division. Our Schoology implementation is an example of that exceptional partnership with student learning. Schoology is our learning management system and has been a crucial tool to meet the needs of teachers and students during this time of extended closure. speaker: Unknown

text: Thank you, Nita. First, I would like to thank the board for the investments you've made in our divisions one-to-one initiative, improved internet access, and new online learning platforms. These investments have allowed us to meet significant challenges to providing continuity of learning during this unusual time.  While the division has done a great job of providing our students with access to personal learning devices, and there has been much attention paid to ensuring that students have broadband internet access at school, the past two months have shown us that without the additional step of ensuring that all students have reliable access to the internet at home, barriers to realizing the goal of providing anytime, anywhere access to learning will remain.  I would like to share with you some data that the division collected at the beginning of the school closures that illustrates where these barriers still exist. As part of the Check and Connect program, teachers and other school staff asked students and their families whether or not they had internet access at home. What you are seeing represents information about those students who reported having no internet access at home.  The bar graph in the upper left represents the number of students in each school who reported not having internet access at home. The same data is also broken down by grade level and ethnicity and race in the lower left corner. The map on the right represents each of the 685 students by home address. The larger circles indicate multiple students living at the same address.  The data shows that even within our urban ring, where a variety of broadband Internet access choices exist, there are significant numbers of students who reported not having Internet access in their home. Two of the three elementary schools with the most students reporting a lack of Internet access, Greer and Woodbrook, are in our urban ring.  The data also shows that we have significant numbers of students in our rural, southern, and western areas who are reported not having internet access. Our two smallest schools, Scottsville and Red Hill, reported the second and fifth most students lacking internet access among all elementary schools. Looking at the map reinforces the conclusion that our students living in the urban ring and the western and southern ends of our county represent the largest portion of our students with this challenge.  When we start looking at the data through the lens of race and ethnicity, we can easily see that our Hispanic-Latino students are disproportionately represented in the group of students who reported not having internet access. While Hispanic-Latino students make up only 14% of our student population, they make up almost 40% of the reporting students. One thing that isn't shown graphically here but is helpful to understanding why our Hispanic-Latino student population is overly represented in this data is looking at our economically disadvantaged statistics.  Overall, 73% of our Hispanic Latino students were classified as economically disadvantaged on our most recent state report. 542 of the 685 students reporting that they had no internet access, 79%, were classified as economically disadvantaged on that same report. This most likely doesn't come as any surprise, but it does illustrate that internet access is closely related to socioeconomic status.  Lastly, I would like to mention that the graphical representation of this data was put together by Sarah Dusenberry, our data and reporting specialist, using our new data analysis and reporting application, Power BI. Our team looks forward to providing more data in this format in the coming months to help the board, division staff, and school administrators to best use data to inform decision making. The data collection was facilitated by Bert Jacobi, our coordinator of digital equity.  Bert is now going to share with you what the division is doing with this data to improve students' access to learning.
speaker: markleach

text: Thank you, Mark. Good evening, everyone. After administrators submitted the roughly 700 names of staff and students who reported that they had no internet access, we first mailed hotspots to staff members and then used a lottery system to select the secondary students who would be mailed a hotspot.  We actually had enough inventory to provide hotspots to all high school students who indicated to their administrators that they would use it, including entering and rural households. We use maps provided by cell phone providers to estimate which carrier would work best at each home. Once staff and students receive their hotspots, we asked them to complete an internet speed test paired with a mapping tool so that we could get verified data on their internet speeds.  rather than relying on a third party that might inflate speed and coverage information to bolster sales. In order to make this information useful as we plan to distribute hotspots to students in the future, post-pandemic, I reached out to Chris Biernan, a teacher at Albemarle High School, to see if there was a way that ArcGIS could make the data more easily digestible. text: Thank you, everyone. It's a pleasure to be here. As you can imagine, this is an incredible time to be involved with educational technology. I'd like to share with you a small handful of the many stories that have come out of our classrooms over the past few weeks.  And in addition to the short stories, I'll share some of the strategies of support provided by the learning technology integrators and some of the existing digital citizenship supports that I believe are really paying off during this unique situation. It goes without saying that our teachers are the true heroes here. They've been masterful in their ability to leverage  technology tools at their disposal at their disposal and provide continuity to our families. It's teachers like Reva Allen and Kristen Fayard from Scottsville. They jumped right into Seesaw. It's a new blended learning platform and portfolio tool that we've brought in for elementary schools. They simultaneously wrapped around their students without a connection to the internet  They advocated early for these students and within days they had high quality activities ready to go, including hard copy assignments in the mail, as well as a concise list of students who needed devices.  Julie Heffron, a chemistry teacher at Albemarle High School. Midway through the year, she started working twice a week with our learning technology integrator, and she worked to build coursework into Schoology. Julie represents one of many teachers who are new to technology.  Julie saw the value of using Schoology's structure to meet her students' diverse needs. Because of this effort, she was well prepared for our transition to virtual learning. Teachers like Megan Copley, a counselor at Hollymead, she's gone above and beyond to create a sense of consistency and support for the social and emotional well-being of her students. In partnership with specialists, she created a Bitmoji  and an interactive world within Seesaw to leverage levity and hyperlinks to engage with students.  Finally, Dana Keck, a teacher from Stone Robinson, has daily read-alouds to her kids. She's hatched baby chicks, filmed their growth, and shared this as a learning experience for her students. I've been told that Dana finds creative ways to make sure these experiences are shared with every single student.  Consistently, the LTIs have shared with me how ACPS teachers have squared their shoulders to the challenges presented by COVID-19, whether it's teachers driving to hotspots for meetings, bundling curriculum onto flash drives, leaving packets on the doorsteps of households, or reading bedtime stories. Like I've said, teachers are truly the heroes here.  With regard to the strategies used by the learning technology team, the LTIs have developed PD for Seesaw and Schoology. They've acted as essential thought partners for teachers and administrators, and they've worked to identify the very best way to provide virtual instruction.  Our LTI, Brian Squires, worked closely with Mary Heppner at Crozet Elementary to help deliver student broadcasts via Zoom. Adam Seiple, our LTI at Albemarle High School, worked closely with Dara Bonham to quickly provide access to student work via public-facing digital folders in the days following March 13th.  Charlie Nolan and Lucy Spencer, as you see pictured here, developed a powerful tool. And it's a tool that identifies four levels of access and the specific platforms teachers should consider when planning instruction. With tools like this, the LTIs have been well-positioned to ensure equity and continuity. To further support our teachers, the learning technology team has provided virtual office hours, attended countless PLC meetings, held  PD sessions over Zoom, checked in on teachers by virtually walking their school, reviewing school directories and making sure each teacher has been checked on. They've also worked directly with our families. Finally, I do want to highlight the culture of digital citizenship that has been present in our school division prior to the onset of COVID-19. It takes time for children to learn the safe and holistic use of technology.  I believe wholeheartedly that both the family field guide pictured here and the countless hours of digital citizenship instruction provided in our schools has prepared our students for learning at home. I want to thank our principals, teachers, and most notably, our librarians for partnering with us as stewards of our digital citizenship culture and curriculum. Thank you again for the opportunity to share this information about our teachers and our LTIs.
speaker: ellenosborne

text: You bet.  OK, next up is the Virginia Board of Education's Model Guidance for Preventative Code of Conduct. And I want to introduce Dr. King for this. text: All right, how's that? Thank you. All right, wonderful. Good evening, board members. And I would like to thank you all for this opportunity. Tonight, what I'd like to do is really just two things briefly. I'd like to really just try to give you an overview of kind of what the model guidance for positive and preventive code of conduct  policy is all about. We are at the beginning of our work in this regard. And so I'd like to share with you a little bit about what it what it means and talk just a bit about what it will mean in terms of how it will impact how we work with students around behavior as a school division going forward. So the model guidance is  the Virginia Board of Education's most recent revision of its student code, student conduct policy guidelines. These guidelines were initially developed in 1994 in response to a requirement established by the General Assembly for the State Board. This revision was developed by a group of diverse educators from across the Commonwealth of Virginia, working in various focus groups,  That work began in 2017 and concluded early in 2019. Beginning at the start of next school year, the 2021 school year, all schools across the Commonwealth will be required to adopt and revise their regulations on codes of conduct that are consistent with, but may be more stringent than these guidelines.  So what are the key components of the model guidance? It does many things. And some of the things that I would like to point out to you is that number one, it uses language that describes students' behavior with a developmental lens, as opposed to a language that looks at behavior from a criminal lens. And I'll be able to provide you with just a few quick examples of that before we're done tonight. Another thing that's really exciting for those of us who work as school administrators is that it will  eliminate the infamous decodes of disruptive disrespectful defiant disorderly research out there is pretty clear that these codes present particular issues. They are infamously and tend to account for in many respects nearly 60% of students suspensions and that number is sometimes even higher. As we look at outcomes  for students who are divergent community. So we're really excited about the elimination of those code. The model guidance also defines the responsibilities of various stakeholders who work in school very definitively. And those roles include defining the role of the principal all the way down to  the role that school nurses would play in developing a safe, supportive, and effective school environment. The model guidance provides a graduated system of equitable responses to discipline incidents, and we're going to talk just a little bit about that in a little bit of detail down the road. It also categorizes student behavior so adults can respond more appropriately to students' developmental needs and do that in an equitable manner.  And finally, it defines and encourages community partnerships to improve school climate and the conditions for learning in our schools. So I mentioned that the model guidance categorizes student behavior. So one of the things that you're going to learn is that the model guidance creates five categories of behavior. And as you can see, these categories are very broad. And what I've done here is  I'm going to share each one of them with you and give you just a couple of examples. So for instance, category A would be behaviors that impede academic progress. And some examples of that might be interfering with learning in the classroom. If you just start with that first one, interfering with learning in the classroom, you can see that would be an infraction there that I would suggest in place.  something like disruptive. And as you can see right off the bat, more descriptive because it speaks specifically to what was going on as opposed to this kind of broad nebulous notion of disrupting class. But that's just one example. Category B would be behaviors related to school operations. These might be dress code violations or unauthorized use of school electronic or other equipment.  Category C, behaviors that create negative relationships. They respond to the directives of staff members or their questions and speaking to another student in an uncivil or a discourteous manner. Category D is behaviors that create a safety concern. Examples there might be leaving school grounds. You can imagine how that would create a safety concern for a student.  and property without force. And then finally, category E, behaviors that endanger self or others. Now, in addition to creating those categories, all of the behaviors in the model guidance are also, there are also suggested levels  of administrative response. And this is where it does become a bit prescriptive for schools. And we think it actually is pretty important because it does establish some pretty strict parameters in terms of infractions, where in school divisions will have the authority to impose exclusionary consequences, including suspension, and those that certainly will not warrant it. And as you said,  up new for the commonwealth. So a level one behavior response, I should say administrative response to behavior, obviously be intended to prevent the behavior from occurring, but also keeps the child in school. And so some examples of that would be reteaching or modeling of desired behavior or having a student go on a work with a staff member.  on a behavior chart. Level two administrative response to behavior would be actions that are intended to prevent the behavior again, but also keep the student in school. But this time it may become necessary and school division would be authorized to remove a student from a classroom, but again, not necessarily remove them from school. So some of those kinds of responses  might be mediation or conflict resolution or referral to support services or referral to a counselor or maybe a behavioral specialist that working in a school community. Level three behaviors and things begin to ratchet up here. These are behaviors, responses that would be intended to address behavior that are chronic in nature and again, create safety concerns.  And so you do begin to see the availability of exclusionary responses like detention and short-term suspension. These of course would become the more serious behaviors that would be a concern there. Level four are behaviors that may result in short-term out-of-school suspension and in some instances might end up with the reporting of that incident to the superintendent or the superintendent's designee.  that being myself. And some of the responses that administrators might use there might be again, long-term revocation of privileges or referral of a student to my office for hearing in response to the behavior. And then level five behaviors, these are of course, these would be the responses that administrators would engage when students have engaged in the most serious kinds of behavior. In almost every sense, in almost every situation,  Those behaviors would require a referral to the superintendent or designee and would expose the student to the possibility of long-term suspension and even in most extreme cases, the possibility of expulsion. So how will disciplinary practices change as a result of the model guidance? And what will it mean? What will be different about the way our administrators will operate?  I just wanted to pull out a few specific things that I thought were important to mention here. The first one is that the model guidance is going to encourage administrators to systemize the use of the restorative questioning. This is something that's near and dear to us here in Albemarle County Public Schools. We use and have used restorative questioning for some time. I think we may have the only superintendent in the Commonwealth who walks around with a pocket full of  restorative questioning cards to pass out to staff members. And so Dr. Haas will be excited about this. But what this does is it asks administrators to think about the student's behavior and talk with the student about the behavior that they've engaged in, in very specific ways, to think really about not just what happened, but what the student thought about what happened, whether or not a student understands,  who it is that was impacted by that behavior and how that student might think about making the thing right that is behavior impacted. So for instance, what would happen in this scenario is a kid, whereas in the past, a kid might come to the office and the administrator might simply take what the parent, excuse me, what the teacher said in the referral in terms of what happened and then just say to the kid what happened.  This would look at having a more deep conversation with the student and asking the student to think really deeply about kind of the impact of their behavior. Going forward, one of the reasons that we want to look at these restorative practices is because we believe it's going to provide us with an opportunity to do behaviors with social emotional skills. Things that's critical in the model guidance is the recognition  that student behavior is often a result of a student not being well prepared to address and operate properly as it relates to some emotional skills. And so we would want to speak with kids and make some determinations about which ones of these social emotional skills a student's behavior indicates some need for improvement in.  so that we could have that be a part of our response to that student's behavior. So once an administrator, thinking through how the model guidance would ask us to operate, once an administrator thinks about what's going on with the kid, in the past, most often the way we've responded to student behavior has been with sanctions, all right? And sanctions being, you know, another word for them being consequences.  class removal, loss of privileges, short-term, and even long-term suspensions. The model... restoratively, as well as thinking about social-emotional skills, the hope with the model... in addition, or rather than simply responding to students' behavior with sanctions, will now be in a position to respond to that behavior with instructional supports, behavioral support,  sanctions or some combination of those three. And what that does is it provides an opportunity for administrators to respond in a more robust way to a student's behavior. So rather than simply moving a student out of a classroom, but that student's behavior is not where we want it to be, it would give us the opportunity to think about how we might provide the student with direct support around improving that behavior,  provide that student with how to improve that behavior. This is particularly exciting for us because in Albemarle County Public Schools, we feel like with some of the work that we've done in years past, we are in a particularly positive position as it relates to doing this. This is going to be one of the places where our work around step or third term educational program is going to be particularly useful and particularly helpful. So,  we will already have in place a model, a resource that will provide us with the space where we can provide that kind of instructional support and behavioral support rather than simply being in a position to have to use a sanction or a significant sanction for a student. So,  That's just my brief overview of kind of what we're going to be doing relative to the model guidance. There are some local decision making and implementation steps that we'll be working through over the next month or so. While each county is required to adopt regulations related to the model guidance, we do have some decisions that we can make.  So for instance, with the leveled administrative responses, school divisions can determine that they would like, those administrative responses have already been leveled by the folks who did the work relative to the model guidance. But school divisions can determine that they'd like to shift some of those levels, move some behaviors up or move some behaviors down. And so one of the things that we'll be doing as a division, we'll have a team will be in place  that will review and revise those leveled administrative responses. In addition, there'll be a team or a group of educators that will work to review and revise the assigned levels of responses. Then we'll also need to think about the means by which teachers and staff will report student discipline issues to school administrators. So obviously as we move to this new program, our traditional behavioral referral process or behavioral  referral document will no longer be useful, so we'll be needing to think about how we will address that as an issue. That's another place where the division, we feel like we also have some of that work already done. A couple of years ago, Mark Leach and I worked to develop an electronic disciplinary referral model that we feel like is going to be useful for this process, but we'll think through that as well. Then finally, we'll need to redesign the ACPS behavior  management handbook so that it now reflects the model guidance. One thing that I do need to share that I missed earlier is one portion of the, it's still a bit in the future, is the implementation of the SBAR system. In the past, and actually currently, at the end of each year, we report discipline data to the state  through a process that's called the Discipline Crime and Violence Report. That system is going away. It had been scheduled to go away after this year's reporting, but as the result of the COVID-19 changes, the state has put that change off for a year. So we will have one more year of working with the Discipline and Violence Report  And then at some point going into the following school year, we will begin to use the new SBAR system. Once that system is made available, it hadn't been made public yet. Once it's made available, I'll be glad to come back and share with the board what it's gonna look like for us going forward. All right. And so the final thing that I'd like to do is share some data about suspensions.  From last school year, or the current school year, Dr. Haas asked me to share this data. First, the first slide here obviously is total out-of-school suspensions. I would note that this data reflects out-of-school suspensions from August to February, obviously so that the numbers are comparative. So from August to February last year, we had a total of 401 out-of-school suspensions.  from August to February this year, we reduced that number by 100 suspensions, and we're down to 301 overall suspensions in the district this year. So I think that's a positive. Also looking at total out of school suspensions by ethnicity and race, you'll note the dark blue would be 2018,  in 2019. Glad to report that in all areas except one, all of the groups of students except one, we saw pretty significant reductions in terms of the number of suspensions for our students by ethnicity year over year. Specifically, total out-of-school suspensions for Black students  In 2018-19, from August to February, there were 98 suspensions of Black students. And from August to February of this school year, that number was reduced to 65. That is a reduction of 34%, so a third of the suspensions. We reduced that number by a third this year. And then finally, Dr. Haas set a goal earlier this year.  No. Lost my stuff here. Dr. Haas set a goal this year to reduce black students, suspension of black students to 20% or fewer of the total out of school suspensions for the 2019-2020 school year.  I am glad to report that we did have a significant reduction, as I showed before. Unfortunately, we did not quite make that 20% number. We did end up at 22%. So African-American or Black student suspensions came in at 22% of total suspensions this year. That's 2% lower than the year before and relatively close to the goal that Dr. Haas set for us last year.  That concludes my sharing. I'll be glad to answer any questions you have.

text: So the first thing I'd say is that one of the things that we did this year that I think had a pretty significant impact on the reduction in terms of  suspensions for Black students is the Implementation of the Superintendent's Out-of-School Suspension Case Review Protocol. We use that protocol exclusively for Black students this year. Administrators weren't required to do it for other students. Just today, I completed  the revision of policy JGB, which is the board policy that regulates out of school suspension. And we actually wrote into that policy the use of that protocol for all suspensions beginning next year. And so I anticipate that  as we continue to implement STEP across the division and as we move forward with the superintendent's suspension review, case review protocol, we will see suspensions continue to reduce and see them continue to reduce across all student groups.  One of the things that's important to think about, and I talked with Dr. Haas about this the other day, or actually someone else. The wonderful thing about that protocol is that what it does is that it reinforces for our administrators the notion that as a school division, we're going to support them when they decide to be creative about the way they respond to student behavior in ways that don't include out-of-school suspension.  And so that is something that becomes particularly important and particularly useful. I can tell you that there are oftentimes when, you know, I have conversations with the administrators who would like to not suspend the student, but are concerned that it's not going to be well received if they don't suspend the student for a specific incident. And what this protocol allows us to do is to help them get comfortable with the notion  that they can actually safely keep students in school and make sure that everyone else around them is safe. And once administrators get in that place, they are certainly less likely to impose suspensions and actually look for additional opportunities to reduce those suspensions. So I'm confident and optimistic that as we go forward,  With the use of that tool and the step tool, we'll continue to see significant reductions. So in a couple of weeks, you will receive that policy revision, and I trust that you all will approve it. And we'll be ready to implement that in the fall and hopefully begin to see additional reductions in our suspension rates.

Because the issue is once the referral is written and once the incident  happens or it's interpreted as to happen, then the referral is written and then all of a sudden it lands in the principal's office and then the principal has to do something with it. What we want to be able to do is to start looking for patterns in our teachers and the numbers of referrals that they write, the numbers of referrals that they write disparately impacting minority students.  And then working with those staff members with professional development so that they can become more culturally responsive and less punitive in their work with the students. And the piece that Nick talked about earlier where he worked with Mark Leach to develop an electronic discipline referral, that's really the key because we're developing dashboards now that'll be coming to the board pretty soon. Sarah Dusenberry's working on those.  And right now we're still using suspensions as a climate aspect of the dashboard for a school. And again, that's after the referral's already written. And so there's that whole layer underneath it that we need to tap into and expose and put in front of the board and start to get strategic about how do we work with the classroom teachers.

text: COB Charles Ferro, COB OSMP, he or hes. : Sorry, the last item on our agenda is the school board salary advertisement and I just wanted to give a bit of a background on this.  is that the School Board has adopted the procedure currently used by the Board of Supervisors in setting its members' salary pursuant to Virginia Code Section 15.2-1414.3. Specifically, the School Board will establish its members' salaries by affirmative vote between May 1st and June 30th annually.  If the salary increase is approved by an affirmative vote, then the increase will take effect on July 1st. Currently, Albemarle County School Board members receive an annual salary of $6,907. The current chair stipend is an additional $1,800 annually, and the vice chair receives a stipend of $35 per meeting chair.  The Board of Supervisors also pays its chair a stipend of $1,800 annually, and the vice chair a stipend of $35 per meeting shared.
